text: The integration workflow stalled because two teams used different handover procedures. Documentation had mismatched version histories, and stakeholders disputed which requirement set was the latest.

Client escalated concerns because no concrete evidence was presented for the milestone completion. Most arguments during the review were assumption-driven rather than supported by logs or validation data.
Design and testing groups interpreted the requirement differently, causing a scope change and generating rework.
Architecture and delivery teams gave conflicting impact assessments for the same change, requiring leadership to resolve the disagreement.
The configuration document lacked metadata and contained inconsistent environment values, creating confusion around deployment readiness.
An urgent client request bypassed the approval workflow, disrupting downstream dependencies and creating sequencing delays.
Requirements changed repeatedly without proper traceability or documentation, leaving no audit trail.
Two managers assumed different owners for the delivery item, causing delays due to lack of accountability.
The functional specification and the user manual described different behaviors for the same feature.
A severity-1 defect remained unassigned for 24 hours, leading to client escalation and exposing contact matrix issues.
